verses.text: These are the last words of David: The declaration of David the son of Jesse, the declaration of the man raised on high, the anointed of the God of Jacob, the sweet psalmist of Israel:
verses.comment: David is identified as both king and prophet, emphasizing God's choice and anointing. The phrase 'sweet psalmist of Israel' links his kingship and spiritual leadership.

verses.text: The Spirit of the Lord spoke by me, and His word was on my tongue.
verses.comment: David affirms inspiration by God's Spirit, foreshadowing the idea of God's word coming through human agents. This establishes prophetic tradition fulfilled in Christ.

verses.text: 'The God of Israel has spoken; the Rock of Israel has said to me: One who rules over people justly, ruling in the fear of God,
verses.comment: The Rock refers to God's steadfastness. A just ruler must have reverence for God, echoing God's kingship. Prefigures Christ, the perfectly just ruler.

verses.text: is like the morning light when the sun rises, a morning without clouds—like shining grass after rain.'
verses.comment: Righteous leadership is compared to new light and growth. This points to renewal and blessing through God's chosen king, a symbol fulfilled by Jesus.

verses.text: For does not my house stand so with God? For He has made with me an everlasting covenant, ordered and secure in all things. Will He not cause my whole salvation and all my delight to grow?
verses.comment: David recalls God's eternal covenant, referencing promises for his descendants. This underlines the unbroken covenant fulfilled in the coming of the Messiah and the continuation of God's kingdom.

verses.text: But worthless men are all like thorns, cast away, for they cannot be taken with the hand.
verses.comment: The wicked are compared to thorns—useless and destined for burning. This foreshadows Christ's warnings about judgment.

verses.text: But the man who touches them must use iron or the shaft of a spear, and they are completely burned with fire where they fall.
verses.comment: The destruction of the wicked is inevitable and absolute. This image of fire recalls New Testament descriptions of final judgment.

verses.text: These are the names of David’s mighty men: Josheb-basshebeth the Tahkemonite was chief of the three; he wielded his spear against eight hundred men whom he killed at one time.
verses.comment: The focus now shifts from David’s final words to a historical listing of his warriors, recalling Israel's tradition of recording the mighty deeds of God's servants.

verses.text: Next to him among the three mighty men was Eleazar, the son of Dodo the Ahohite. He was with David when they defied the Philistines who were gathered for battle. The men of Israel withdrew,
verses.comment: Even in times when others fall away, God’s faithful remain. This points to those who remain steadfast in faith in all times and circumstances.

verses.text: but he stood firm and struck down the Philistines until his hand grew weary and clung to the sword. The Lord brought about a great victory that day. The people returned after him only to strip the slain.
verses.comment: Though Eleazar fought bravely, the victory is attributed to the Lord, showing that even heroic effort is ultimately the work of divine grace.

verses.text: Next to him was Shammah the son of Agee the Hararite. The Philistines gathered for battle at a plot of ground full of lentils, and the people fled from the Philistines.
verses.comment: Shammah’s story reinforces courage under pressure and the theme of one faithful person standing for many. Often God uses a remnant.

verses.text: But he stood in the midst of the field, defended it, and struck down the Philistines. The Lord brought about a great victory.
verses.comment: Victory is the Lord’s, even when won through human instruments. This foreshadows God's continual action through chosen mediators.

verses.text: Three of the thirty chief men went down at harvest time and came to David at the cave of Adullam, while a band of Philistines was encamped in the Valley of Rephaim.
verses.comment: The cave of Adullam was a place of refuge, alluding to God’s protection and the gathering of the faithful remnant.

verses.text: David was then in the stronghold, and the garrison of the Philistines was then in Bethlehem.
verses.comment: Bethlehem, David’s birthplace, becomes symbolic—later the birthplace of the Messiah, Jesus. This prefigures Messianic prophecy.

verses.text: David longed and said, 'Oh, that someone would give me water to drink from the well of Bethlehem that is by the gate!'
verses.comment: David’s longing for water from Bethlehem is reminiscent of Psalm 42’s spiritual thirst, symbolizing longing for God's presence.

verses.text: The three mighty men broke through the camp of the Philistines, drew water out of the well of Bethlehem that was by the gate, took it, and brought it to David. But he would not drink of it, and poured it out to the Lord.
verses.comment: David offers the water as a libation to the Lord—indicating that what is most precious belongs to God, a theme deepened in other offerings and ultimately Christ’s sacrifice.

verses.text: He said, 'Far be it from me, O Lord, that I should do this. Shall I drink the blood of the men who went at the risk of their lives?' Therefore, he would not drink it. These things the three mighty men did.
verses.comment: David equates the water with the blood of his men, reflecting the sacredness of life. The idea of 'offering' prefigures the language of sacrifice seen in the New Covenant.

verses.text: Now Abishai the brother of Joab, the son of Zeruiah, was chief of the thirty. He lifted his spear against three hundred and killed them, and had a name among the thirty.
verses.comment: Abishai’s valor brings unity and hope among Israel's warriors, a reminder of the importance of spiritual community.

verses.text: Was he not the most honored of the thirty? Therefore he became their commander, but he did not attain to the three.
verses.comment: A hierarchy among the warriors is recognized, paralleling the ordering of leadership among God’s faithful people, prefiguring spiritual authority.

verses.text: And Benaiah the son of Jehoiada, a valiant man from Kabzeel, a doer of mighty deeds, struck down two sons of Ariel of Moab. He also went down and killed a lion in the midst of a pit on a snowy day.
verses.comment: Benaiah’s mighty deeds prefigure the extraordinary acts of God’s saints—acting with courage that comes from faith.

verses.text: He struck down an Egyptian, a man of great stature. The Egyptian had a spear in his hand, but he went down to him with a staff, seized the spear from the Egyptian’s hand, and killed him with his own spear.
verses.comment: Benaiah’s victory over a giant recalls that of David and Goliath—repeating the theme that God's chosen prevail not by strength alone, but by God’s help.

verses.text: These things did Benaiah the son of Jehoiada, and he had a name among the three mighty men.
verses.comment: Being 'named' signifies spiritual distinction. In the biblical tradition, names reveal vocation and honor.

verses.text: He was more honored than the thirty, but he did not attain to the three. And David set him over his personal guard.
verses.comment: Benaiah’s appointment signals the trust and responsibility given to faithful servants—a type for stewardship in spiritual leadership.

verses.text: Among the thirty were Asahel the brother of Joab, Elhanan the son of Dodo of Bethlehem,
verses.comment: The listing continues, showing how personal fidelity binds many individuals to a greater purpose in God’s plan.

verses.text: Shammah the Harodite, Elika the Harodite,
verses.comment: Many names in these lists are not as familiar, which highlights that many who invisibly serve God are recorded in His memory.

verses.text: Helez the Paltite, Ira the son of Ikkesh the Tekoite,
verses.comment: These verses continue to connect the historical legacy between Samuel, Chronicles, and the transmission of the tradition.

verses.text: Abiezer the Anathothite, Mebunnai the Hushathite,
verses.comment: Geographical names illustrate the unity of God's people from various regions brought together in the service of the king.

verses.text: Zalmon the Ahohite, Maharai the Netophathite,
verses.comment: Unity in diversity is shown in the composition of David’s mighty men.

verses.text: Heleb the son of Baanah the Netophathite, Ittai the son of Ribai of Gibeah of the people of Benjamin,
verses.comment: The tribe of Benjamin’s presence among these men reiterates the gathering of all Israel under God’s king.

verses.text: Benaiah a Pirathonite, Hiddai of the brooks of Gaash,
verses.comment: Even small and lesser-known towns are represented, underscoring that all places and people contribute to God’s purposes.

verses.text: Abi-albon the Arbathite, Azmaveth the Barhumite,
verses.comment: Each name, preserved for generations, witnesses the value God places on every contributor to His mission.

verses.text: Eliahba the Shaalbonite, the sons of Jashen, Jonathan,
verses.comment: The remembrance of mighty deeds by these individuals anticipates the biblical record of the cloud of witnesses (Hebrews 12:1).

verses.text: Shammah the Hararite, Ahiam the son of Sharar the Hararite,
verses.comment: Lists like these highlight faithfulness across generations—a theme fulfilled as God's people persevere through history.

verses.text: Eliphelet the son of Ahasbai, the son of the Maacathite, Eliam the son of Ahithophel the Gilonite,
verses.comment: Ahithophel's family serves alongside other Israelites, showing that service and even redemption is possible for those linked to troubled stories.

verses.text: Hezro the Carmelite, Paarai the Arbite,
verses.comment: Each name uniquely matters, expanding the idea of the communion of saints and the unity of the people of God.

verses.text: Igal the son of Nathan of Zobah, Bani the Gadite,
verses.comment: Names from the northern tribes testify to the widespread faithfulness that built David’s kingdom.

verses.text: Zelek the Ammonite, Naharai of Beeroth, the armor-bearer of Joab the son of Zeruiah,
verses.comment: Even foreigners and those of non-Israelite origin were integrated, mirroring the opening of God’s covenant to all nations.

verses.text: Ira the Ithrite, Gareb the Ithrite,
verses.comment: Ithrites’ inclusion shows the range of backgrounds serving within the unified kingdom under David.

verses.text: Uriah the Hittite—thirty-seven in all.
verses.comment: Uriah’s inclusion is particularly striking. Though a Gentile, he is honored among David’s mightiest. His fidelity stands as a model of ultimate loyalty even in the midst of human failure and sin in leadership; this anticipates God’s power to sanctify those from every background through faithfulness.
